article.title: Acceleration profiles and processing methods for parabolic flight
funding: MIT Media Lab Space Exploration Initiative
article.abstract: Parabolic flights provide cost-effective, time-limited access to “weightless” or reduced gravity conditions, facilitating research and validation activities that complement infrequent and costly access to space.

sections.introduction: Parabolic flights are cost-effective, ground-based analogs that achieve variable g (Earth-relative GIA) level environments that recreate conditions experienced during space flight.
sections.methods: The Slam Stick X™ (Mide Technology Corp.) was selected based on its size (76 mm × 30 mm × 15 mm), low mass (65 g), integrated battery, manual and USB interfaces, and combination DC (Analog Devices ADXL345) and piezoelectric (TE 832M1) accelerometers to enable accuracy at both low (e.g., down to 0 Hz) and high frequencies (up to 20 kHz sample frequency).
sections.results: Flight operations were conducted on November 17, 2017 onboard a Boeing 727-200F aircraft (G-Force One®, Zero Gravity Corporation). Four sets of parabolas were performed with 5, 6, 4, and 5 parabolas, respectively.
sections.discussion: Parabolic flights provide the opportunity to perform simulated space research in a cost-effective manner.

article.insights_summary: Parabolic flights provide cost-effective, time-limited access to “weightless” or reduced gravity conditions, facilitating research and validation activities that complement infrequent and costly access to space.
article.acknowledgments: We thank the MIT Media Lab Space Exploration Initiative for providing the parabolic flight.
